thread.title: Roo cull changes cuts legal options for activists
thread.title_full: Roo cull changes cuts legal options for activists

title: Roo cull changes cuts legal options for activists
text:
Map: Canberra 2600 
Animal activists will find it harder to challenge this year's controversial kangaroo cull after the ACT Government removed the need for a culling licence. 
The Government said one of the legal avenues used by conservationists to challenge the annual cull had been removed, by declaring the eastern grey kangaroo a "controlled native species". 
Under the Government's new management plan, released today, it states once an animal is placed in the category ACT Parks and Conservation no longer needs to apply for a licence to manage the animal and its impacts — including culling it. 
In previous years, groups such as Animal Liberation ACT have unsuccessfully challenged the cull licences in the ACT Civil and Administrative Tribunal (ACAT). 
Conservator for Flora and Fauna Annie Lane said the change to the Nature Conservation Act in 2014 meant this year's cull would avoid costly legal fees. 
"We've had four challenges in ACAT in 2009, 2012, 2013 and 2014," she said. 
"All of those were unsuccessful and we also had an independent and external review of the counting methodology in 2014, so the science has stood up. 
"The appeals process has been avoided and that's how we create efficiencies and reduce costs to the community." 
Animal Liberation ACT had argued there was no scientific evidence to prove reducing kangaroo numbers helped the environment. 
But the Government has long maintained a cull was needed to protect native grassland from overgrazing since kangaroos were no longer kept in check by predators. 
Dr Lane said, despite the legal changes, she would still be responsible for setting the number of animals to cull. 
"The conservator has a very important role to play in authorising the numbers and being satisfied that the science behind those numbers is robust," she said. 
Last year 1,989 adult kangaroos and 800 pouch young were killed — up about 400 animals altogether from 2015. 
Dr Lane said while ACT Parks and Conservation was exempt, other property owners would still need a licence to participate in the cull. 
A trial is still underway for a kangaroo contraceptive program .
